title: The Seed of Trust
devotional:
Old Man Hemlock was known in the village for his gnarled hands and even gnarlier disposition. He lived alone in a small cottage at the edge of the woods, and rarely spoke to anyone. The villagers whispered stories about him, tales of a bitter old man who had lost everything and closed his heart to the world. One day, a young boy named Thomas, known for his unyielding curiosity and boundless optimism, decided to visit Old Man Hemlock. Against the advice of his parents, Thomas ventured into the woods and knocked on the door of the cottage.

To his surprise, the door creaked open, revealing the old man, his face etched with wrinkles and weariness. Thomas, undeterred, simply smiled and offered the old man a small bouquet of wildflowers he had picked along the way. Hemlock hesitated, then reluctantly accepted the flowers. Day after day, Thomas visited Hemlock, offering small gifts and sharing stories of the village. Slowly, almost imperceptibly, Hemlock began to soften. He started sharing stories of his own, tales of a life filled with love, loss, and regret. He spoke of a wife he had adored, a family he had lost too soon, and the bitterness that had consumed him in the years that followed.

One afternoon, Thomas asked Hemlock, "Why did you stop trusting?" Hemlock looked down at his hands, the skin paper-thin with age. "Because," he rasped, "life showed me it couldn't be trusted." Thomas, in his youthful wisdom, replied, "But you have to trust *someone*. You have to trust *something*." Hemlock paused, and looked at Thomas. "Trust is like planting a seed," Thomas continued. "You have to bury it, even when you can't see what will grow. You have to water it, even when the sun is hidden. And you have to believe, even when all you see is dirt."

The old man, touched by the boy's sincerity, realized that he had allowed his past pain to blind him to the possibility of future joy. He had closed himself off from the world, refusing to trust that anything good could still come his way. He started attending church with Thomas's family every Sunday and started sharing stories with the rest of the community. Over time, the villagers came to see Hemlock not as a bitter old man, but as a wise elder who had learned from his mistakes and found redemption through the simple act of trusting again. Life doesn't guarantee that things will work out, but trusting that God will be present is a guarantee.
image_description: A close-up view of a single, small sprout emerging from dark, rich soil, with sunlight gently illuminating the delicate leaves.
insights: Hemlock's transformation mirrors the biblical call to trust in God, even in the face of adversity. Proverbs 3:5-6 encourages us to 'Trust in the Lord with all your heart and lean not on your own understanding; in all your ways submit to him, and he will make your paths straight.' This passage doesn't promise a life free from hardship, but it does assure us that God will guide us if we place our trust in Him. Similar to the planting of a seed, our trust requires faith and perseverance, even when we can't see the immediate results.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I confess that I often struggle to trust You when life is difficult. Help me to remember that Your love is unwavering and Your guidance is constant. Grant me the strength to release my fears and embrace the unknown, knowing that You are always with me. Teach me to trust in Your plan, even when I can't see the path ahead. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: Where in your life do you find it difficult to trust God? What steps can you take to cultivate a deeper sense of trust in His plan? How can you remind yourself of His faithfulness during times of uncertainty?
